name: Fontaine–Mazur conjecture
rephrased: The Fontaine–Mazur conjecture states that any p-adic Galois representation that is almost entirely unramified (only ramified at finitely many primes) and behaves well at p-adic primes (specifically, is potentially semi-stable) must originate from the geometric properties of some algebraic variety.
implication_form: If a p-adic representation of a number field's Galois group is almost everywhere unramified and potentially semi-stable, then it arises from the étale cohomology of some algebraic variety.
posed_by: Jean-Marc Fontaine and Jean-Marc Messing (commonly attributed to Fontaine and Mazur, though Mazur is sometimes mentioned).
explained: The Fontaine–Mazur conjecture consists of two main parts concerning p-adic Galois representations and number fields. First, it states that a p-adic representation of the absolute Galois group of a number field arises from algebraic geometry (e.g., étale cohomology) if and only if it is almost everywhere unramified and potentially semi-stable at p (equivalent to de Rham at p). Second, it conjectures that a number field has no infinite unramified pro-p extension for any prime p.
